introduction.p: In Chapter 4 we saw that the amplitude, period, and midline of a sinusoidal graph are determined by the coefficients in its formula. The circular functions (sine and cosine of real numbers) behave the same way.

subsection.title: Period, Midline, and Amplitude
subsection.p: Changes to the amplitude, period, and midline are called transformationstransformation of the basic sine and cosine graphs.

ul.li: Changing the midline shifts the graph vertically.
Changing the amplitude stretches or compresses the graph vertically.
Changing the period stretches or compresses the graph horizontally.

subsection.p: First, we'll consider changes in amplitude.

statement.p: Compare the graphs of f(x)=2\sin (x) and g(x)=0.5\sin (x) with the graph of y=\sin (x).

solution.p: Use technology to graph the three functions for -2\pi \le x \le 2\pi. The graphs are shown below.
All three graphs have the same period (2\pi) and midline (y=0), but the graph of f has amplitude 2, and the graph of g has amplitude 0.5.

subsection.p: The amplitude of y=A\sin (t) is given by \abs A, and the same is true of y=A\cos (t). In the next exercise, remember that the amplitude is always a nonnegative number.

statement.p: Compare the graphs of f(x)=3\cos (x) and g(x)=-3\cos (x) with the graph of y=\cos (x).

answer.p: Both graphs have amplitude 3. The graph of g(x)=-3\cos (x) is reflected about the x-axis.

subsection.p: Next, we'll consider changes in the period of the graph.

statement.p: Compare the graphs of f(x)=\cos (2x) and g(x)=\cos \left(\dfrac{1}{3}x\right) with the graph of y=\cos (x).

solution.p: Use technology to graph f(x)=\cos (2x) and y=\cos (x) for -2\pi \le x \le 2\pi, as shown below.
Both graphs have the same amplitude (1) and midline (y=0), but the graph of f completes two cycles from 0 to 2\pi instead of one. The period of f(x)=\cos (\alert{2}x) is \dfrac{2\pi}{\alert{2}}=\pi.
Now graph g(x)=\cos \left(\dfrac{1}{3}x\right) and y=\cos (x) for 0 \le x \le 6\pi.
The graph of g(x)=\cos \left(\alert{\dfrac{1}{3}}x\right) completes one cycle between 0 and 6\pi. Its period is \dfrac{2\pi}{\alert{\frac{1}{3}}}=6\pi.

subsection.p: The period of y=\cos (Bt) is given by \dfrac{2\pi}{\abs B}, and the same is true of y=\sin (Bt).

ol.li: Compare the graph of f(x)=\sin (3x) with the graph of y=\sin (x)for 0 \le x \le 2\pi.
Compare the graph of g(x)=\sin \left(\dfrac{1}{4}x\right) with the graph of y=\sin (x) for 0 \le x \le 8\pi.
The graph of f completes 3 cycles from 0 to 2\pi. Its period is \dfrac{2\pi}{3}.
The graph of g completes one cycle from 0 to 8\pi. Its period is 8\pi.

subsection.p: Next we'll consider changes in midline.

statement.p: Compare the graph of f(x)=2+\sin (x) with the graph of y=\sin (x).

solution.p: Graph both functions -2\pi \le x \le 2\pi. The graphs are shown below.

Each point on the graph of f(x)=2+\sin (x) has y-coordinate 2 units higher than the corresponding point on the graph of y=\sin (x). Thus, the graph of f(x)=2+\sin (x) is shifted vertically by 2 units relative to the graph of y=\sin (x). In particular, the midline of f(x)=\alert{2}+\sin (x) is the line y=\alert{2}.

statement.p: Compare the graph of g(x)=-3+\cos (x) with the graph of y=\cos (x).

answer.p: The graph of g is shifted down 3 units. Its midline is y=-3.

subsection.p: Here is a summary of our findings.

assemblage.title: Amplitude, Period, and Midline of Sinusoidal Functions

ol.li: The graph of y=A\cos (x) ~~~~\text{or}~~~~ y=A\sin (x) has amplitude \abs A.
The graph of y=\cos (Bx) ~~~~\text{or}~~~~ y=\sin (Bx) has period \dfrac{2\pi}{B}.
The graph of y=k+\cos (x) ~~~~\text{or}~~~~ y=k+\sin (x) has midline y=k.

subsection.title: Graphs of Sinusoidal Functions
subsection.p: The values of the parameters A,~ B, ~ \text{and}~ k determine the shape of the graphs of y=k+A\sin (Bx) ~~~~\text{or}~~~~ y=k+A\cos (Bx) By adjusting the amplitude, period, and midline of the sine or cosine graph, we can sketch these sinusoidal functions.

ol.li: State the amplitude, period, and midline of y=2+3\cos (4t).
Sketch by hand a graph of y=2+3\cos (4t).
The amplitude of the graph is 3, its midline is y=2, and its period is \dfrac{2\pi}{4}=\dfrac{\pi}{2}.

subsection.title: Modeling with Sinusoidal Functions
subsection.p: Sinusoidal functions are used to model a great variety of physical phenomena, including sound and light waves, tides and planetary orbits, and the life cycles of plants and animals. They are also often used to approximate periodic functions that are not exactly sinusoidal, such as blood pressure.

statement.p: A typical blood pressure for a healthy adult, measured in millimeters of mercury, varies between 70 and 110, and a typical heart rate is 60 beats per minute. Write a sinusoidal function that approximates blood pressure, and sketch its graph.

solution.p:
We would like a function of the form y=k+a\sin (Bt), so we must find the values of the parameters A,~B and k.
The midline of the graph is y=\dfrac{70+110}{2}=90, and the amplitude is 110-90=20, so A=20 and k=90.
The graph repeats 60 times per minute, so the period is \dfrac{1}{60} minute, and B=\dfrac{2\pi}{\frac{1}{60}}=120\pi.
Thus, y=90+20\sin (120 \pi t) The graph of the function is shown below.

note.p: In the preceding Example, we could have chosen either a sine or a cosine function to model blood pressure; both describe the periodic behavior described. However, if we are given, or would like to specify, the starting point for a sinusoidal function, one choice can be more suitable than the other. Consider the functions graphed below.

All four functions have the same amplitude and period, but they start at different points on the cycle.
The graphs in (a) and (b) start on the midline, so they are best modeled by sine functions.
The graph in (b) starts out decreasing instead of increasing, so the coefficient A is negative.
The graph in (c) is modeled by a cosine, because it starts at the maximum point, and the graph in (d) starts at the minimum point, so we choose a negative cosine to model it.

subsection.title: The Tangent Function
subsection.p: The transformations of shifting and stretching can be applied to the tangent function as well. The graph of y=\tan x does not have an amplitude, but we can see any vertical stretch by comparing the function values at the guidepoints.

ol.li: Graph y=1+3\tan (2x).
Describe the transformations of the graph, compared to y=\tan (x).

li.p: Recall that the period of the tangent function is \pi. We make a table of values for one cycle of the function, choosing multiples of \dfrac{\pi}{4} as the inputs for the tangent function. Then we plot the guidepoints, and sketch a tangent function through them. The graph is shown below.

Writing the formula as y=A\tan (Bx)+k=3\tan (2x) +1 we see that the graph is stretched vertically by a factor of A=3. The midline is y=1, so the graph is shifted up by 1 unit. Finally, the coefficient B=2 compresses the graph horizontally by a factor of 2, so the period of the graph is \dfrac{\pi}{2}, and there are four cycles between 0 and 2\pi
